body:
@tqchen Good idea. I have one problem before I can make this fully useful. For the Julia GPU codegen we have a NDArray-like type that exists on the GPU so you can just write normal Julia code and use all the convenience methods of Julia arrays on the GPU. Currently `decorate` inserts the shape of the array into the code we compile qith nvrtc, but on the Julia side I can't do that. Instead I would need to setup the array object in GPU memory and then set the data pointer to the NDArray. 

Any idea how to non-disruptively do this with the current code path?
@NoListen It's merged now. Please have a try.
can you give more detailed logs?
it's good to have a single page containing all things. but total agree that we can open issue for each point and cite the links here.
I guess since you are directly inserting PTX you can set your own convention about how to handle ptr and shape. All the codegen is happening in Julia right?
you are missing some libraries. Check Kaldi version and follow the instructions closely
Yes, I just then also need to launch the kernel with that convention.
try broadcast_mul instead of *

I see. I can think of two ways:
1. Add a void \* params at the end that contains frontend specific parameter to kernel
2. Make a Julia specific rtc module and put it in julia
@mli Yes. If someone wants to talk more about/start working on a task, feel free to open a new issue and link it here. Also assign it to milestone v1.0
First please check whether you compile with CuDNN. Another issue is check default size of image. To use multi-GPU, you probably need to change gram symbol by using batch-dot.
Would it be acceptable to have code like https://gist.github.com/vchuravy/ec05e427e99e4ef32d64934f3959a17b in the main repository or should I develop this as a plugin?
@Darwin2011  NNPACK is there already if you use the CaffeOp and pull https://github.com/ajtulloch/caffe/tree/nnpack-pr into your Caffe branch btw :)
@pluskid @antinucleon Is there anything I can do to help? I could try writing a masking layer in python using mx.operator.CustomOp if it's possible, what do you guys think?
@EasonD3  getting the same in EC2 g2.2.
I'm getting similar issues with a EC2 instance, using prefetch_buffer=1.
@martinbel , my experience is that the labels are loaded at once into RAM (I've got >100GB labels to load..). I'm actually using g2.8xlarge which only has 60GB RAM.

@EasonD3 You mean, your training set has 100GB of images? I'm not sure what you mean by "labels". I've converted the images to the `.rec` files as shown in [the docs](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/io.html#create-dataset-using-recordio). The .rec files (compresed) are small and fit in my RAM, the raw images wouldn't for the instance I was using. I'm getting the same in my own computer, I need to kill it after 5 seconds. 
The library seems promising, but I just wasn't able to make it work with my data, which doesn't make it much useful for me (as I'm not using the benchmark datasets).
@antinucleon 谢谢你的回答，但是"change gram symbol by using batch-dot"指什么？可以具体讲一下吗？或者具体如何实施？
I followed strictly and no use.
kaldi I tried the latest version and 5.1 version all build error.

I did not follow the instruction and do as follows:

# 编译kaldi

## 编译tools

进入tools，运行

```
make
```

## 编译src

进入src(不需要按照mxnet说明 ./configure --shared)，运行

```
./configure
make depend
make
```

and the following build passed.
But I don't know whether is there any bad side effect.

@martinbel , sorry about the confusion. My problem is very similar to the one stated in the original post, where each image is associated with hundreds of thousands of labels/classes (i.e., multi-label problem). If you feed `path_imglist` with the labels of all images in `ImageRecordIter`, all of the labels will be loaded for one time into RAM before the training starts. So in my case, the label file is too huge to load them directly in `ImageRecordIter`.
@sxjscience Could you explain it for me?
@piiswrong is this a bug?

Should I add the hosts file?
I see 
    if args.cluster == 'local' or args.host_file is None  args.host_file == 'None':
        from dmlc_tracker import local
        local.submit(args)
    if args.cluster == 'sge':
        from dmlc_tracker import sge
        sge.submit(args)
    elif args.cluster == 'yarn':
        from dmlc_tracker import yarn
        print '------- go yarn ---'
        yarn.submit(args)
    elif args.cluster == 'ssh':
        from dmlc_tracker import ssh
        ssh.submit(args)
    elif args.cluster == 'mpi':
        from dmlc_tracker import mpi
        mpi.submit(args)
    else:
        raise RuntimeError('Unknown submission cluster type %s' % args.cluster)

Does it mean I need to add the hosts file when I use sge, yarn, ssh OR mpi?

@HrWangChengdu could you have a look.

Could you also provide a simple code snipplet that produce this problem?

I remember to enable GPUDirect on the same machine, just simply call [`cudaDeviceEnablePeerAccess` ](http://horacio9573.no-ip.org/cuda/group__CUDART__PEER_g9e5ea65a18938c2b8715a5602105c306.html) and then all the memory copies will automatically use GPUDirect. 
The example code is in `cuda_sdk/samples/1_Utilities/p2pBandwidthLatencyTest`. 
Do we have some kind of initialization part of all the mxnet contexts? If so, we could add the code there.

it may be due to the image compression algorithm used by python is not good... please consider try to download a converted data at http://data.dmlc.ml/mxnet/private/ilsvrc12/, *_256_q90.rec 

please shoot me an email muli@cs.cmu.edu for the username and password
it's virtual memory
it's used by the dmlc/rabbit project

data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
data = mx.sym.CaffeOp(data_0=data, num_weight=2,
                          prototxt='''layer{type:\"Convolution\" convolution_param { num_output: 128 pad: 1 kernel_size: 3 stride: 1 }}''')
...

model = mx.model.FeedForward(       symbol=data ........)
model.fit( ..... , kvstore=local_allreduce_device)
Could you run mxnet/example/caffe/caffe_net.py on multi-gpu? That works fine for me.
I checked, it was not the virtual memory, if I increase the sample number, the python.exe will crash due to not enough memory, and the total memory is 16GB.

I forget to specify the num-servers when using dmlc-submit. This will be ok
`python dmlc-submit --cluster ssh --num-wokers 2 --num-servers=2 --host-files hosts python test.py --kv-store dist_sync`
By the way, the multi-node program still can't be canncelled with new dmlc-submit. Is there any way to avoid it ? @mli
got it. did you read the whole dataset into memory? or using .rec format. what's your batch size?
@mli done
@tqchen ImageRecordIter seems to be doing too much prefetching which is over engineering now that networks are usually big enough.

I run the example . when I use kv-store = 'local' ,it works fine.

But if kv-store = 'local_allreduce_device', train-top-accuracy don't increase.
@mli @tqchen

![screen shot 2016-08-09 at 3 06 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12552820/17505798/cf5a4832-5e42-11e6-9837-c0690587c71f.png)
I have made some tests for different dilation size and I found if dilation!=1, this question seemed to be very obvious. The table below shows the gpu memory for different dilation size with or without reshape (means fixed input size or various input size). We can see that when dilation=1, everything is very normal, but when it is equal to 2, there is a big memory usage, for various input size. fixed size has a big increase as well but not that significant. Then with the dilation size increases, the memory usage seems to drop.
The code I used to make the test was just my previous reply. Is this normal? Is there supposed to be big memory usage when dilation is bigger than 1? @piiswrong @tqchen
The batch size is 32, .rec format is used as the data input.

When dilation > 1 we use mxnet's own conv layer instead of cudnn because it
doesn't support dilation.
Could you try turn off cudnn and see if dilation still has this effect?

mx.io.CSVIter
I think it's better to put it in jl repo, or as a plugin

@piiswrong Thanks for your reply!
does mx.io.CSVIter support distributed reading? I find mxnet.io.ImageRecordIter has parameters： `num_parts  part_index`  for distributed reading and mx.io.CSVIter has no such parameters
@piiswrong   broadcast_mul solved this problem, thank you!
@amanaman118 which `gcc` version do you use? is it `gcc-5` or 4.8 something?
got it now,thanks.
For spatial conv kernel dim is of course 2, just like you set in the symbol, kernel = (7, 7) etc. I don't see anything wrong here

@amanaman118 seems like you have updated some package but the old link libs are not yet removed, so the code is trying to link to an old lib but failed. It usually happens on `dmlc-core` since it is one of the most dependent. Please check out a very fresh repo and try again.
For a convolution layer with `f` feature maps out  and `c`  feature maps in, the total kernel shape is (f, c, k, k). Kernel size is (k, k). You may mistake that (c, k, k) is a kernel.
There is not. Please ignore this line and supply aux_params as saved in training.

@winstywang I'm sorry. I just follow the neural art in the examples and there is one step of initializing the parameters to 0. Even the white noise image as a container is initialized as `mx.nd.zeros(content_np.shape, ctx=dev)`

I initialize the image and find the error. However, I can run the neural-art program with no error just now.  I think you are right. Thank you, I will close it.

@HrWangChengdu Thank you very much and it doesn't interrupt again. Moreover, I think that it's necessary to add `num_weight num_out` arguments when there are many weights and many outputs. Very nice work! I was lucky to use the `CaffeOp` as soon as it was delivered.

May be I didn't say it clearly. I know what you say.  Let me say the input image is a 32x32x3, so the depth is 3. For the first conv layer, each kernel's spatial 3x3 and the depth is equal to the layer in front of these kernels, so the kernel's depth is also 3. For a general case: the input is WxHxD, if the kernel's spital size is 3x3, then the shape of these kernels in current conv layer is 3x3xD. The more detialed explanation in https://cs231n.github.io/convolutional-networks/ @winstywang @feiyulv

@EasonD3 In my case the label's file isn't huge, but I get the same error. I guess something isn't working well with the `mx.io.ImageRecordIter`. I don't have so much data, but it crashes. I also don't see how a labels file can get to have 100 GB, that's insane!
Please refer to this isssue (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2783)
I would recommend you to try your code with simple model (such as three fully connected layers), to test whether there's something wrong.

I get the same error on windows. Run mxnet the first time it works. The second run it fails and throws the following error
 Error in mx.ctx.default() : 
  object 'mx.ctx.internal.default.value' not found

If I restart R studio it works again for one run of the code
I think it may due to call `asnumpy` and sync write, eg `a[:] = b` too often, this will block async execution. We will provide a high level API for seq2seq.

Please refer to mx.io.NDArrayIter with this example (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/tutorial.ipynb)

Document is somehow not so well-organized. I would recommend you read all the examples in example/notebook before really go into work.
@freddycct Thank you! I am also looking into other framework to see how they deal with padding mask
Ok closing for now

Will update this to only contain LeakyReLU 

@Godricly thank you for picking up the work in #2824

Thanks for the pointers. A quick look-through seems to answer all my points! I'll have a look through the rest of the notebooks just for safe measure.

Thanks!
You need to shard your data across machines and use different input file for each machine

@EasonD3 ImageLabelMap in src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc read the whole label file on init and Find() return label given index. You can change it to open a database on init and return label from database.
You can use leveldb, lmdb, or rocksdb for this
Another potential issue is kernel fusion. I think it can be solved by using CuDNN RNN op and a C++ implementation of RNN. I am doing a refactor on general RNN API.

@tornadomeet Min has successfully reproduced Res-50/101/152/200 even in distributed environment. For Res-200 he reported exact performance but trained in 36 hours with multiple machine. We will reproduce it together with you.

great!!
@HrWangChengdu This sound like some synchronization issue. Caffe probably use the default stream (Does it? I'm not sure) so you need to sync on the default stream at the end of forward/backward
@liuzhi136  `D` is determined by the input channel number, so the kernel need not set it explicitly.

@piiswrong Without using Cudnn, this effect still exists. For example, using dilation=12, fixed input size uses 600MB, while various input size has more than 4GB usage, since my 4GB gpu is out of memory. More importantly, this time, even with dilation=1, the system got out of memory when there is various input size since cudnn is disabled.
Are you using current master? https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2927 should fix this problem
@piiswrong thx. I'm checking on this.
I have used mxnet in many networks. there is no any problem.
@tornadomeet Thank you. Do you know where is the code that automatically set the D parameter? I want to see how does it work. Thank your for your reply.

@liuzhi136 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/convolution-inl.h#L98-L103  wmat_shape is the kernel shape, just consider num_group=1 for better understanding,data.shape_[1] means `D`
Pooling and Dropout have been merged.

@antinucleon @piiswrong @tornadomeet 
Maybe I don't show my task specific.
I have a dataset contains 10W images and every image has two labels like -1.257 and 4.325.
So I follw the im2rec.py build the lst file like:

```
98572   -1.7156 1.257   1200292226/20100406_065150.jpg
98573   -1.7445 1.2286  1200292226/20100406_070056.jpg
98574   -1.7823 1.1922  1200292226/20100406_071240.jpg
98575   -1.8101 1.1661  1200292226/20100406_072106.jpg
98576   -1.8762 1.1067  1200292226/20100406_074035.jpg
98577   -1.9201 1.0694  1200292226/20100406_075301.jpg
98578   -1.9601 1.0371  1200292226/20100406_080359.jpg
```

Then I use the tool im2rec transform the lst file to rec file with label_width=2

The purpose of my task is making a prediction of a image and generate the two number like the type in lst file of the image at the same time.

Then I copy `find_mxnet.py`,`train_model.py`,`train_alexnet.py`,`symbol_googlenet.py` provided in mxnet/example/image-classfication to my folder 
And built my net in `symbol.mynet.py`.(I have renamed this file) The last layer of my net is:

```
s2_fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=s2_relu5, num_hidden=2)
linearRegression = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=s2_fc2, name="softmax")
return linearRegression
```

**Q1----I have searched in google about multi-label task in mxnet and I have notice that the last layer of my net   may be wrong. But I don't know how to write the output layer in the correct way.**

I built my dataiter in `train_mynet.py` with ImageRecordIter

```
def get_iterator(args, kv):
    data_shape = (3, args.data_shape, args.data_shape)
    train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = os.path.join(args.data_dir, args.train_dataset),
        mean_img = "/home/deeper/10W-project/ye_train.bin",
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        path_imglist= "/home/deeper/10W-project/ye_train.lst",
        label_width = 2,
        batch_size  = args.batch_size,
        num_parts   = kv.num_workers,
        part_index  = kv.rank)
    val = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = os.path.join(args.data_dir, args.val_dataset),
        mean_img = "/home/deeper/10W-project/ye_train.bin",
        rand_crop   = False,
        rand_mirror = False,
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        path_imglist= "/home/deeper/10W-project/ye_val.lst",
        label_width = 2,
        batch_size  = args.batch_size,
        num_parts   = kv.num_workers,
        part_index  = kv.rank)

    return (train, val)
```

**Q2-----All  preparations of my task is show above. But the training process is going on only when I set the batch_size=1.  I  will encounter the error'AttributeError: 'bool' object has no attribute 'sum'' when I change the batch_size. Can you give me some advise with your professional eye.**

--------------update---------------
With the files and code I have prepared, I have found the error `AttributeError: 'bool' object has no attribute 'sum'`  occured when I train in multi-label. Everything going on when I'm training in the single label.

@tornadomeet Thank you. I have read it. It make sense if the data.shape_[1] is the depth of the input. One more question, how many dimensions the data have? Is it 2? the first dimension is W \* H and second one is D? Is that right?
memory release is async. could you post your code?
strictly speaking, the weight shape is (c_out, c_in, k_h, k_w), but it's only the  continuous address in the memory, so don't need too care about these, you can reshape it to any shape size.

@piiswrong I just modified the C++ example "image-classification-predict.cc" in MXNet. The sequence of function calls is as follows:
(1) MXPredCreate
(2) MXPredSetInput
(3) MXPredForward
(4) MXPredGetOutput
(5) MXPredFree
@tornadomeet c_in is the number of channel of input and c_out is the number of channel of output in current conv layer?
yes
If u used (1,1), your pooling kernel will move with step size of 1. The output size is almost the same with feature map before pooling.

@piiswrong I just updated mxnet to the lastest one and I dont think the issues has been fixed. Nevertheless, it seems the issue has been mitigated but still obvious. For example, with cudnn, if I use dilate=12, with fixed input size=(1,2048,80,80), the memory usage is around 600MB. However if I used reshape to get a new shared-weights executor with a new input size(even though the new size is equal to the previous one), the memory usage increased to 1800MB (three times). I have tried using other dilate values, I observed at least 2 times bigger of memory usage.

A minimal reproducing example would be helpful
@piiswrong I still cannot pass example after adding cudaStreamSyn on my machine.
@tornadomeet  I appreciate your explanation. Thank you so much.
U need to change train_model.py a little bit to enable this. There is a [parameter](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L415) to do this.
@HrWangChengdu "device" works for me but 'local_allreduce_device' doesn't. It's so strange. They should be the same thing

You can use your own optimizer in this way.

```
opt = mx.optimizer.SGD(
    learning_rate=0.01,
    momentum=0.9,
    wd=0.00001)

model.fit(data,opt, ...)
```
